bitmark:
[.book]
[@id:230865]
[#Adjektiv/Adverbien]
[@language:de]
[@coverImage:https://docs.bitmark.cloud/bit-books/englisch-hilfen/web-resources/images/englischhilfen_grammatik_cover.png]
[@externalId:e-adjektivadverbien_gmx-p3pzek1w]

[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:230866]
[%Nr. 1010]
[!Setze das Wort in Klammern entweder als Adjektiv oder als Adverb ein.]

0.Peter works [_slowly][@example].

1. He [_quickly][!quick] reads a book.
2. Mandy is a [_pretty][!pretty] girl.
3. The class is [_terribly][!terrible] loud today.
4. Max is a [_good][!good] singer.
5. You can [_easily][!easy] open this tin.
6. It's a [_terrible][!terrible] day today.
7. She sings the song [_well][!good].
8. He is a [_careful][!careful] driver.
9. He drives the car [_carefully][!careful].
10. The dog barks [_loudly][!loud].

bit.body:
0.Peter works {0}.

1. He {1} reads a book.
2. Mandy is a {2} girl.
3. The class is {3} loud today.
4. Max is a {4} singer.
5. You can {5} open this tin.
6. It's a {6} day today.
7. She sings the song {7}.
8. He is a {8} driver.
9. He drives the car {9}.
10. The dog barks {10}.
bit.instruction: Setze das Wort in Klammern entweder als Adjektiv oder als Adverb ein.

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:230867]
[%Nr. 1034]
[!Setze das in Klammern stehende Wort entweder als Adjektiv oder als Adverb ein.]

0. Peter works [_slowly][@example].

1. The bus driver was [_seriously][!serious] injured.
2. Kevin is [_extremely][!extreme] clever.
3. This hamburger tastes [_awful][!awful].
4. Be [_careful][!careful] with this glass of milk. It's hot.
5. Robin looks [_sad][!sad]. What's the matter with him?
6. Jack is [_terribly][!terrible] upset about losing his keys.
7. This steak smells [_good][!good].
8. Our basketball team played [_badly][!bad] last Friday.
9. Don't speak so [_fast][!fast]. I can't understand you.
10. Maria [_slowly][!slow] opened her present.

bit.body:
0. Peter works {0}.

1. The bus driver was {1} injured.
2. Kevin is {2} clever.
3. This hamburger tastes {3}.
4. Be {4} with this glass of milk. It's hot.
5. Robin looks {5}. What's the matter with him?
6. Jack is {6} upset about losing his keys.
7. This steak smells {7}.
8. Our basketball team played {8} last Friday.
9. Don't speak so {9}. I can't understand you.
10. Maria {10} opened her present.
bit.instruction: Setze das in Klammern stehende Wort entweder als Adjektiv oder als Adverb ein.

[%Nr. 1052]
[!Die folgenden Wörter enden alle auf -ly.

[-Adjektiv]
[+Adverb]

[!2.carefully]

[+Adverb]

[!3.friendly]

[-Adverb]

[+Adverb]
===

[-Adverb]
===
[!6.quickly]
[-Adjektiv]
[+Adverb]
===
[!7.ugly]
[+Adjektiv]
[-Adverb]
===
[!8.heavily]
[-Adjektiv]
[+Adverb]
===
[!9.badly]
[-Adjektiv]
[+Adverb]
===
[!10.early]
[+Adjektiv]
[+Adverb]
===

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:230870]
[%Nr. 1080]
[!Schreibe die Gegenteile der gesteigerten Adjektive in die Lücken. Beachte das Beispiel.]

0. longer → [_shorter][@example]

1. older → [_younger]
2. cheaper → [_more expensive]
3. colder → [_hotter]
4. more boring → [_more interesting]
5. warmer → [_cooler]
6. better → [_worse]
7. more difficult → [_easier]
8. smaller → [_bigger]
9. more → [_less]
10. drier → [_wetter]

bit.instruction: Schreibe die Gegenteile der gesteigerten Adjektive in die Lücken. Beachte das Beispiel.

[@id:230872]
[%Nr. 8038]
[!Wähle aus den Vorgaben die richtige Vorsilbe (im-, in-, un-) aus.]

1. cool  → [-im][-in][+un]cool
2. direct → [-im][+in][-un]direct
3. popular → [-im][-in][+un]popular
4. clear → [+im][+in][-un]clear
5. polite → [+im][-in][-un]polite
6. important → [-im][-in][+un]important
7. tidy → [-im][-in][+un]tidy
8. human → [-im][+in][-un]human
9. fair → [-im][-in][+un]fair
10. true → [-im][-in][+un]true

bit.body:

2. direct → {1}direct
3. popular → {2}popular
4. clear → {3}clear
5. polite → {4}polite
6. important → {5}important
7. tidy → {6}tidy
8. human → {7}human
9. fair → {8}fair
10. true → {9}true

a story

[%2]read

a book
===

a video
===
[%7] play

a game
===
[%8]make 
==
the beds
===

==
a skateboard
===

a photo
===

bitmark:

[▼ch-5]
[@id:230883]
[#Wortbildung]

[.multiple-choice-text:bitmark--]
[@id:230884]
[%Nr. 8018]
[!Bestimme die richtige Wortart. Suche dir zu den englischen Wörtern auf der linken Seite die passende Wortart auf der rechten Seite aus.]

1. new → [+Adjektiv][-Adverb][-Ausruf][-Konjunktion, Bindewort][-Präposition][-Pronomen][-Substantiv][-Verb]
2. happily → [-Adjektiv][+Adverb][-Ausruf][-Konjunktion, Bindewort][-Präposition][-Pronomen][-Substantiv][-Verb]
3. read → [-Adjektiv][-Adverb][-Ausruf][-Konjunktion, Bindewort][-Präposition][-Pronomen][-Substantiv][+Verb]
4. she → [-Adjektiv][-Adverb][-Ausruf][-Konjunktion, Bindewort][-Präposition][+Pronomen][-Substantiv][-Verb]
5. house → [-Adjektiv][-Adverb][-Ausruf][-Konjunktion, Bindewort][-Präposition][-Pronomen][+Substantiv][-Verb]
6. but → [-Adjektiv][-Adverb][-Ausruf][+Konjunktion, Bindewort][-Präposition][-Pronomen][-Substantiv][-Verb]
7. on →  [-Adjektiv][-Adverb][-Ausruf][-Konjunktion, Bindewort][+Präposition][-Pronomen][-Substantiv][-Verb]
8. Hello! → [-Adjektiv][-Adverb][+Ausruf][-Konjunktion, Bindewort][-Präposition][-Pronomen][-Substantiv][-Verb]

bit.instruction: Bestimme die richtige Wortart. Suche dir zu den englischen Wörtern auf der linken Seite die passende Wortart auf der rechten Seite aus.

bitmark:
[.multiple-choice-text:bitmark--]
[@id:230885]
[%Nr. 8020]
[!In den folgenden Sätzen sind Wörter unterstrichen. Bestimme die Wortart.]
1. Steve __can__ play the trumpet. [-Adjektiv][-Adverb][+Hilfsverb][-Substantiv][-Verb]
2. Do you __like__ dogs? [-Adjektiv][-Adverb][-Hilfsverb][-Substantiv][+Verb]
3. They __listen__ to music every day. [-Adjektiv][-Adverb][-Hilfsverb][-Substantiv][+Verb]
4. She is an __old__ lady. [+Adjektiv][-Adverb][-Hilfsverb][-Substantiv][-Verb]
5. The __group__ went climbing in the mountains. [-Adjektiv][-Adverb][-Hilfsverb][+Substantiv][-Verb]
6. This is a __fast__ car. [+Adjektiv][-Adverb][-Hilfsverb][-Substantiv][-Verb]
7. He did __well__ in the test. [+Adjektiv][-Adverb][-Hilfsverb][-Substantiv][-Verb]
8. My father drives __carefully__. [-Adjektiv][+Adverb][-Hilfsverb][-Substantiv][-Verb]
9. Has your __father__ ever been to Australia? [-Adjektiv][-Adverb][-Hilfsverb][+Substantiv][-Verb]
10. The __play__ was fantastic. [-Adjektiv][-Adverb][-Hilfsverb][+Substantiv][-Verb]

bit.instruction: In den folgenden Sätzen sind Wörter unterstrichen. Bestimme die Wortart.

bitmark:
[.multiple-choice-text:bitmark--]
[@id:230886]
[%Nr. 8048]
[!Wie wird das unterstrichene Wort im Satz verwendet? Wähle aus den Vorgaben die richtige Form aus.]
1. Jack likes __reading__. → [-Adjektiv][+Substantiv][-Verb]
2. We are __sitting__ on a bench. → [-Adjektiv][-Substantiv][+Verb]
3. I love __sparkling__ water. → [+Adjektiv][-Substantiv][-Verb]
4. __Parking__ is expensive in cities. → [-Adjektiv][+Substantiv][-Verb]
5. They read an __interesting__ article yesterday. → [+Adjektiv][-Substantiv][-Verb]
6. Look! The boy is __catching__ crabs. → [-Adjektiv][-Substantiv][+Verb]
7. The __crying__ child was taken to hospital. [+Adjektiv][-Substantiv][-Verb]
8. She has been __watching__ videos the whole evening. → [-Adjektiv][-Substantiv][+Verb]
9. I'm good at __telling__ stories. → [-Adjektiv][+Substantiv][-Verb]
10. Do you prefer __jogging or riding?__ → [-Adjektiv][+Substantiv][-Verb]

bit.instruction: Wie wird das unterstrichene Wort im Satz verwendet? Wähle aus den Vorgaben die richtige Form aus.

bitmark:
[.chapter]
[▼ch-8]
[@id:230890]
[#Adjektive/Adverbien]

[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:230891]
[%Nr. 1078]
[!Schreibe den Komparativ und den Superlativ der vorgegebenen Adjektive in die Lücken.]

0. young → [_younger][@example] → [_youngest][@example]

1. cheap → [_cheaper] → [_cheapest]
2. fit → [_fitter] → [_fittest]
3. exciting → [_more exciting] → [_most exciting]
4. cool → [_cooler] → [_coolest]
5. late → [_later] → [_latest]
6. dangerous → [_more dangerous] → [_most dangerous]
7. small → [_smaller] → [_smallest]
8. popular → [_more popular] → [_most popular]
9. happy → [_happier] → [_happiest]
10. boring → [_more boring] → [_most boring]

bit.instruction: Schreibe den Komparativ und den Superlativ der vorgegebenen Adjektive in die Lücken.

bitmark:
[.cloze]
[@id:230892]
[%Nr. 1012]
[!Steigere die Adjektive.]

0. new → [_newer][@example] → [_newest][@example]

1. old → [_older] → [_oldest]
2. bad → [_worse] → [_worst]
3. difficult → [_more difficult] → [_most difficult]
4. large → [_larger] → [_largest]
5. good → [_better]  → [_best]
6. big → [_bigger] → [_biggest]
7. easy → [_easier] → [_easiest]
8. much → [_more] → [_most]
9. little → [_less] → [_least]
10. interesting → [_more interesting] → [_most interesting]

bit.instruction: Steigere die Adjektive.

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:230893]
[%Nr. 1014]
[!Setze die richtigen Formen der Adjektive in die Lücken ein.]

0. [_old][@example] → older → [_oldest][@example]

1. [_long] → longer → [_longest]
2. [_bad]  →  [_worse] → worst
3. modern → [_more modern] → [_most modern]
4. [_nice] → [_nicer] → nicest
5. [_near] → [_nearer] → nearest
6. [_flat] → [_flatter] → flattest
7. popular → [_more popular] → [_most popular]
8. [_happy] → happier → [_happiest]
9. many → [_more] → [_most]
10. exciting → [_more exciting] → [_most exciting]

bit.instruction: Setze die richtigen Formen der Adjektive in die Lücken ein.

bitmark:
[.cloze]
[@id:230894]
[%Nr. 1022]
[!Setze das fehlende Wort in die Lücke. Welche Form du einsetzen musst, siehst du an den ersten zwei Wörtern in jeder Aufgabe.]
1. strong → stronger; good → [_better]
2. coldest → colder; happiest → [_happier]
3. nice → nicer; bad → [_worse]
4. angry → angrier; much → [_more]
5. more boring → boring; sunnier → [_sunny]
6. more interesting → most interesting; worse → [_worst]
7. hard → hardest; new → [_newest]
8. most expensive → expensive; cleanest → [_clean]
9. fast → fastest; old → [_oldest]
10. shortest → short; most difficult → [_difficult]

bit.instruction: Setze das fehlende Wort in die Lücke. Welche Form du einsetzen musst, siehst du an den ersten zwei Wörtern in jeder Aufgabe.

10. [-an electronic new][+a new electronic] guitar

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:230902]
[%Nr. 1060]
[!Vervollständige den Satz, indem du den **Komparativ** des in Klammern stehenden Adjektivs in die Lücke einsetzt.]

0. Marie is [_older][@example] than Lisa.

1. Jake's room is [_smaller][!small] than Larry's room.
2. The blue car is [_nicer][!nice] than the black car.
3. This exercise is [_more boring][!boring] than that one.
4. His pullover is [_darker][!dark] than his jeans.
5. Susan's hair is [_longer][!long] than my hair.
6. George is [_funnier][!funny] than Robert.
7. My result in the test was [_better][!good] than Harry's.
8. Gold is [_more expensive][!expensive] than silver.
9. Christine is [_smarter][!smart] than Alice.
10. Football is [_more popular][!popular] than handball.

bit.body:
0. Marie is {0} than Lisa.

1. Jake's room is {1} than Larry's room.
2. The blue car is {2} than the black car.
3. This exercise is {3} than that one.
4. His pullover is {4} than his jeans.
5. Susan's hair is {5} than my hair.
6. George is {6} than Robert.
7. My result in the test was {7} than Harry's.
8. Gold is {8} than silver.
9. Christine is {9} than Alice.
10. Football is {10} than handball.

[.cloze:bitmark--]

[%Nr. 1062]
[!Vervollständige den Satz, indem du den **Komparativ** des in Klammern stehenden Adjektivs in die Lücke einsetzt.]

0. Dan is [_younger][@example] than Ben.

1. Nick is [_taller][!tall] than Chris.
2. This smartphone is [_cheaper][!cheap] than that one.
3. Kitesurfing is [_more dangerous][!dangerous] than hiking.
4. November is [_colder][!cold] than July in Europe.
5. She always arrives [_later][!late] than her teacher.
6. Tomorrow will be [_sunnier][!sunny] than today.
7. Peggy is [_more careful][!careful] than Vanessa.
8. These headphones are [_worse][!bad] than my old ones.
9. Jack's car is [_faster][!fast] than mine.
10. He's [_more intelligent][!intelligent] than his brother.

bit.body:
0. Dan is {0} than Ben.

1. Nick is {1} than Chris.
2. This smartphone is {2} than that one.
3. Kitesurfing is {3} than hiking.
4. November is {4} than July in Europe.
5. She always arrives {5} than her teacher.
6. Tomorrow will be {6} than today.
7. Peggy is {7} than Vanessa.
8. These headphones are {8} than my old ones.
9. Jack's car is {9} than mine.
10. He's {10} than his brother.

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:230904]
[%Nr. 1032]
[!Setze das **fettgedruckte** Adjektiv aus dem ersten Satz in der richtigen Steigerungsform (Komparativ oder Superlativ) in den zweiten Satz ein.]

0. I have a fast car, but my friend has a [_faster][@example] car.

1. This is a **nice** cat. It's much [_nicer] than my friend's cat.
2. Here is Emily. She's six years **old**. Her brother is nine, so he is [_funnier] .
3. This is a **difficult** exercise. But the exercise with an asterisk * is the [_most difficult] exercise on the worksheet.
4. He has an **interesting hobby**, but my sister has the [_most interesting] one in the world.
5. In the last holidays I read a **good** book, but father gave me an even [_better] one last weekend.
6. School is **boring**, but homework is [_more boring] than school.
7. Skateboarding is a **dangerous** hobby. Bungee jumping is [_more dangerous] than skateboarding.
8. This magazine is **cheap**, but that one is [_cheaper].
9. We live in a **small** house, but my grandparents' house is even [_smaller] than ours.
10. Yesterday John told me a **funny** joke. This joke was the [_funniest] joke I've ever heard.

bit.body:
0. I have a fast car, but my friend has a {0} car.

1. This is a **nice** cat. It's much {1} than my friend's cat.
2. Here is Emily. She's six years **old**. Her brother is nine, so he is {2} .
3. This is a **difficult** exercise. But the exercise with an asterisk * is the {3} exercise on the worksheet.
4. He has an **interesting hobby**, but my sister has the {4} one in the world.
5. In the last holidays I read a **good** book, but father gave me an even {5} one last weekend.
6. School is **boring**, but homework is {6} than school.
7. Skateboarding is a **dangerous** hobby. Bungee jumping is {7} than skateboarding.
8. This magazine is **cheap**, but that one is {8}.
9. We live in a **small** house, but my grandparents' house is even {9} than ours.
10. Yesterday John told me a **funny** joke. This joke was the {10} joke I've ever heard.
bit.instruction: Setze das **fettgedruckte** Adjektiv aus dem ersten Satz in der richtigen Steigerungsform (Komparativ oder Superlativ) in den zweiten Satz ein.

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:230905]
[%Nr. 1050]
[!Setze das Adjektiv aus dem ersten Satz in der richtigen Steigerungsform (Komparativ oder Superlativ) in den zweiten Satz ein.]

0. I have a fast car, but my friend has a [_faster][@example] car.

1. My father is heavy. My uncle is much [_heavier] than him.
2. The test in geography was easy, but the test in biology was [_easier] .
3. Florida is sunny. Do you know the [_sunniest] place in the USA?
4. Stan is a successful sportsman, but his sister is [_more successful] than him.
5. My mother has a soft voice, but my teacher's voice is [_softer] than hers.
6. Amy has a beautiful baby, but my daughter has the [_most beautiful] baby on earth.
7. I live in a large family, but my grandfather lived in a [_larger] one.
8. We have only little time for this exercise, but in the examination we'll have even [_less] time.
9. Lucy is clever, but Carol is [_cleverer] than her.
10. Have you visited the old castle? It was the [_oldest] one we visited during our holidays.

bit.body:
0. I have a fast car, but my friend has a {0} car.

1. My father is heavy. My uncle is much {1} than him.
2. The test in geography was easy, but the test in biology was {2} .
3. Florida is sunny. Do you know the {3} place in the USA?
4. Stan is a successful sportsman, but his sister is {4} than him.
5. My mother has a soft voice, but my teacher's voice is {5} than hers.
6. Amy has a beautiful baby, but my daughter has the {6} baby on earth.
7. I live in a large family, but my grandfather lived in a {7} one.
8. We have only little time for this exercise, but in the examination we'll have even {8} time.
9. Lucy is clever, but Carol is {9} than her.
10. Have you visited the old castle? It was the {10} one we visited during our holidays.
bit.instruction: Setze das Adjektiv aus dem ersten Satz in der richtigen Steigerungsform (Komparativ oder Superlativ) in den zweiten Satz ein.

bitmark:
[.chapter]
[▼ch-12]
[@id:230910]
[#Adjektive/Adverbien]

[.multiple-choice-text:bitmark--]
[@id:230911]
[%Nr. 1070]
[!Mehrere Adjektive vor einem Substantiv stehen meistens in folgender Reihenfolge:
**Meinung - Größe - Alter - Form - Farbe - Herkunft - Material - Zweck**
Was beschreiben die folgenden Adjektive?]
1. big → [-Alter][-Farbe][-Form][+Größe][-Herkunft][-Material][-Meinung][-Zweck]
2. old → [+Alter][-Farbe][-Form][-Größe][-Herkunft][-Material][-Meinung][-Zweck]
3. great → [-Alter][-Farbe][-Form][-Größe][-Herkunft][-Material][+Meinung][-Zweck]
4. English → [-Alter][-Farbe][-Form][-Größe][+Herkunft][-Material][-Meinung][-Zweck]
5. wooden → [-Alter][-Farbe][-Form][-Größe][-Herkunft][+Material][-Meinung][-Zweck]
6. electronic → [-Alter][-Farbe][-Form][-Größe][-Herkunft][-Material][-Meinung][+Zweck]
7. terrible → [-Alter][-Farbe][-Form][-Größe][-Herkunft][-Material][+Meinung][-Zweck]
8. red → [-Alter][+Farbe][-Form][-Größe][-Herkunft][-Material][-Meinung][-Zweck]
9. little → [-Alter][-Farbe][-Form][+Größe][-Herkunft][-Material][-Meinung][-Zweck]
10. round → [-Alter][-Farbe][+Form][-Größe][-Herkunft][-Material][-Meinung][-Zweck]

bit.instruction:

**Meinung - Größe - Alter - Form - Farbe - Herkunft - Material - Zweck**
Was beschreiben die folgenden Adjektive?

[%Nr. 1074]

**Meinung - Größe - Alter - Form - Farbe - Herkunft - Material - Zweck**

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:230914]
[%Nr. 1030]
[!Benutze in den Sätzen entweder **as ... as** oder **not as ... as**.]

0. Ben Nevis is [_not as high as][@example] Mont Blanc.

1. The blue car is [_ as fast as][!fast] the red car.
2. Peter is [_not as tall as][!not/tall] Fred.
3. The violin is [_ not as low as][!not/low] the cello.
4. This copy is [_as bad as][!bad] the other one.
5. Oliver is [_as optimistic as][!optimistic] Peter.
6. Today it's [_not as windy as][!not/windy] yesterday.
7. The tomato soup was [_as delicious as][!delicious] the mushroom soup.
8. Grapefruit juice is [_not as sweet as][!not/sweet] lemonade.
9. Nick is [_as brave as][!brave] Kevin.
10. Silver is [_not as heavy as][!not/heavy] gold.

bit.body:
0. Ben Nevis is {0} Mont Blanc.

1. The blue car is {1} the red car.
2. Peter is {2} Fred.
3. The violin is {3} the cello.
4. This copy is {4} the other one.
5. Oliver is {5} Peter.
6. Today it's {6} yesterday.
7. The tomato soup was {7} the mushroom soup.
8. Grapefruit juice is {8} lemonade.
9. Nick is {9} Kevin.
10. Silver is {10} gold.
bit.instruction: Benutze in den Sätzen entweder **as ... as** oder **not as ... as**.

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:230915]
[%Nr. 1076]
[!Bilde Sätze, indem du die zwei Wörter mit dem Adjektiv in Klammern vergleichst. Beginne den Satz mit dem ersten Substantiv. Benutze den Komparativ des Adjektivs. Beachte das Beispiel.]

0. bikes /cars __(slow)__ [_Bikes are slower than cars.][@example]

1. Dan / Harry __(young)__ . [_Dan is younger than Harry.]
2. French / English __(difficult)__ . [_French is more difficult than English.]
3. Moscow / London __(big)__ . [_Moscow is bigger than London.]
4. Lisa / Tony __(tall)__ . [_Lisa is taller than Tony.]
5. the black car / the white car __(cheap)__ . [_The black car is cheaper than the white car.]
6. Robert / Henry __(happy)__ . [_Robert is happier than Henry.]
7. dogs / cats __(intelligent)__ . [_Dogs are more intelligent than cats.]
8. my room / your room __(nice)__ . [_My room is nicer than your room.]
9. Tokyo / Paris __(busy)__ . [_Tokyo is busier than Paris.]
10. the girls / the boys __(quiet)__ . [_The girls are quieter than the boys.]

||[.chapter]
[▼ch-13]

[#Spiele]

1044 rebus||

bit.instruction: Bilde Sätze, indem du die zwei Wörter mit dem Adjektiv in Klammern vergleichst. Beginne den Satz mit dem ersten Substantiv. Benutze den Komparativ des Adjektivs. Beachte das Beispiel.

solutions: French is more difficult than English.
The black car is cheaper than the white car.
Dogs are more intelligent than cats.
My room is nicer than your room.
The girls are quieter than the boys.

bitmark:
[.chapter]
[▼ch-14]
[@id:230917]
[#Adjektive/Adverbien]

[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:230918]
[%Nr. 1040]
[!Bilde von folgenden Adjektiven das richtige Adverb.]

0. slow → [_slowly][@example]

1. perfect → [_perfectly]
2. quiet → [_quietly]
3. careful → [_carefully]
4. regular → [_regularly]
5. nice → [_nicely]
6. terrible → [_terribly]
7. heavy → [_heavily]
8. good → [_well]
9. hard → [_hardly]
10. fantastic → [_fantastically]

bit.instruction: Bilde von folgenden Adjektiven das richtige Adverb.

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:230919]
[%Nr. 1042]
[!Steigere die folgenden Adverbien.]

0. newly → [_more newly][@example] → [_most newly][@example]

1. fast → [_faster] → [_fastest]
2. well → [_better] → [_est]
3. carefully → [_more carefully] → [_most carefully]
4. often → [_more often] → [_most often]
5. badly → [_worse] → [_worst]
6. hard → [_harder] → [_hardest]
7. clearly → [_more clearly] → [_most clearly]
8. little → [_less] → [_least]
9. much → [_more] → [_most]
10. early → [_earlier] → [_earliest]

bit.instruction: Steigere die folgenden Adverbien.

bitmark:
[.multiple-choice-text:bitmark--]
[@id:230920]
[%Nr. 1056]
[!Wo steht das Häufigkeitsadverb **always, never, often, seldom, sometimes** im englischen Satz? Wähle die richtige Reihenfolge aus.]
1. We [+always go][-go always] to school by bus.
2. I [-clean often][+often clean] my room on Saturdays.
3. They [+sometimes use][-use sometimes] tablets in the classroom.
4. He [-gets never][+never gets] home before 8 pm.
5. They [-always are][+are always] friendly.
6. The children [+often watch][-watch often] YouTube videos.
7. I [-make seldom][+seldom make] my bed.
8. Our teacher [+is often][-often is] busy.
9. Do they [+never walk][-walk never] to the supermarket?
10. We don't [+always have][-have always] coffee for breakfast.

bit.body:
1. We {0} to school by bus.
2. I {1} my room on Saturdays.
3. They {2} tablets in the classroom.
4. He {3} home before 8 pm.
5. They {4} friendly.
6. The children {5} YouTube videos.
7. I {6} my bed.
8. Our teacher {7} busy.
9. Do they {8} to the supermarket?
10. We don't {9} coffee for breakfast.
bit.instruction: Wo steht das Häufigkeitsadverb **always, never, often, seldom, sometimes** im englischen Satz? Wähle die richtige Reihenfolge aus.

bitmark:
[.multiple-choice-text:bitmark--]
[@id:230921]
[%Nr. 1058]
[!Wo stehen die Häufigkeitsadverbien **always, never, often, seldom, sometimes, usually** in den englischen Sätzen? Wähle die richtige Reihenfolge aus.]
1. She [+always does][-does always] sport in the afternoon.
2. I [-have often][+often have] a shower when I get home in the evening.
3. My parents [+are seldom][-seldom are] strict.
4. We [-go sometimes][+sometimes go] fishing at the lake.
5. I [+am often][-often am] tired.
6. She [+can never remember][-can remember never] his name.
7. He doesn't [+usually smoke][-smoke usually].
8. They [-have never][+never have] enough time.
9. They [+have never had][-never have had] pets.
10. Where do you [-spend usually][+usually spend] your summer holidays?

bit.body:
1. She {0} sport in the afternoon.
2. I {1} a shower when I get home in the evening.
3. My parents {2} strict.
4. We {3} fishing at the lake.
5. I {4} tired.
6. She {5} his name.
7. He doesn't {6}.
8. They {7} enough time.
9. They {8} pets.
10. Where do you {9} your summer holidays?
bit.instruction: Wo stehen die Häufigkeitsadverbien **always, never, often, seldom, sometimes, usually** in den englischen Sätzen? Wähle die richtige Reihenfolge aus.

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:230922]
[%Nr. 1048]
[!Schreibe den kompletten Satz noch einmal und setze das in Klammern stehende Adverb an der Stelle im Satz ein, an der es **normalerweise** steht.]

0. I play tennis. __(on Mondays)__
[_I play tennis on Mondays.][@example]

1. Our friends must write a test. __(also)__ [_Our friends must also write a test.]
2. I was joking. __(only)__ [_I was only joking.]
3. Did you enjoy the flight? __(both)__ [_Did you both enjoy the flight?]
4. Mary watches TV. (hardly) __(ever)__ [_Mary hardly ever watches TV.]
5. He drives his car. __(carefully)__ [_He drives his car carefully.]
6. The children play football. __(in the garden)__ [_The children play football in the garden.]
7. We went to the cinema. __(yesterday)__ [_We went to the cinema yesterday.]
8. John fell off the bike. __(almost)__ [_John almost fell off the bike.]
9. Her boyfriend will buy her some flowers. __(probably)__ [_Her boyfriend will probably buy her some flowers.]
10. My uncle is moving to Stockholm soon. __(definitely)__ [_My uncle is definitely moving to Stockholm soon.]

bit.instruction: Schreibe den kompletten Satz noch einmal und setze das in Klammern stehende Adverb an der Stelle im Satz ein, an der es **normalerweise** steht.

solutions: Our friends must also write a test.
Did you both enjoy the flight?
The children play football in the garden.
We went to the cinema yesterday.
John almost fell off the bike.
Her boyfriend will probably buy her some flowers.
My uncle is definitely moving to Stockholm soon.

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:230923]
[%Nr. 1020]
[!Schreibe den kompletten Satz noch einmal und setze das in Klammern stehende Häufigkeitsadverb an der Stelle im Satz ein, an der es **normalerweise** steht.]

0. I play tennis on Sundays. __(often)__
[_I often play tennis on Sundays.][@example]

1. He listens to the radio. __(often)__ [_He often listens to the radio.]
2. They read a book. __(sometimes)__ [_They sometimes read a book.]
3. Pete gets angry. __(never)__ [_Pete never gets angry.]
4. Tom is very friendly. __(usually)__ [_Tom is usually very friendly.]
5. I take sugar in my coffee. __(sometimes)__ [_I sometimes take sugar in my coffee.]
6. Ramon and Frank are hungry. __(often)__ [_Ramon and Frank are often hungry.]
7. My grandmother goes for a walk in the evening. __(always)__ [_My grandmother always goes for a walk in the evening.]
8. Walter helps his father in the kitchen. __(usually)__ [_Walter usually helps his father in the kitchen.]
9. They watch TV in the afternoon. __(never)__ [_They never watch TV in the afternoon.]
10. Christine smokes. __(never)__ [_Christine never smokes.]

bit.instruction: Schreibe den kompletten Satz noch einmal und setze das in Klammern stehende Häufigkeitsadverb an der Stelle im Satz ein, an der es **normalerweise** steht.

solutions: I often play tennis on Sundays.
He often listens to the radio.
I sometimes take sugar in my coffee.
Ramon and Frank are often hungry.
My grandmother always goes for a walk in the evening.
Walter usually helps his father in the kitchen.
They never watch TV in the afternoon.

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:230924]
[%Nr. 1046]
[!Schreibe den kompletten Satz noch einmal und setze das in Klammern stehende Häufigkeitsadverb an der Stelle im Satz ein, an der es **normalerweise** steht.]

0. I play tennis on Sundays. __(often)__
[_I often play tennis on Sundays.][@example]

1. Have you been to London? __(ever)__ [_Have you ever been to London?]
2. Peter doesn't get up before seven. __(usually)__ [_Peter doesn't usually get up before seven.]
3. Our friends must write tests. __(often)__ [_Our friends must often write tests.]
4. They go swimming in the lake. __(sometimes)__  [_They sometimes go swimming in the lake.]
5. The weather is bad in November. __(always)__  [_The weather is always bad in November.]
6. Peggy and Frank are late. __(usually)__  [_Peggy and Frank are usually late.]
7. I have met him before. __(never)__  [_I have never met him before.]
8. John watches TV. __(seldom)__  [_John seldom watches TV.]
9. I was in contact with my sister. __(often)__  [_I was often in contact with my sister.]
10. She will love him. __(always)__  [_She will always love him.]

bit.instruction: Schreibe den kompletten Satz noch einmal und setze das in Klammern stehende Häufigkeitsadverb an der Stelle im Satz ein, an der es **normalerweise** steht.

solutions: I often play tennis on Sundays.
Have you ever been to London?
Peter doesn't usually get up before seven.
Our friends must often write tests.
They sometimes go swimming in the lake.
The weather is always bad in November.
Peggy and Frank are usually late.
I have never met him before.
I was often in contact with my sister.
